title: Ticket #1823: management of many child heartbeat timers doesn't scale well
description:
When the schedd has 40k-50k running jobs, we observe that it spends a large fraction of its time handling heartbeats from the shadows. A typical call stack looks like this: 

#0  0x000000000059b35c in TimerManager::InsertTimer(tagTimer*) ()
#1  0x000000000059bd90 in TimerManager::ResetTimer(int, unsigned int, unsigned int, bool, Timeslice const*) ()
#2  0x0000000000585ac1 in DaemonCore::HandleChildAliveCommand(int, Stream*) ()
#3  0x00000000005803e2 in DaemonCore::CallCommandHandler(int, Stream*, bool) ()
#4  0x000000000058df57 in DaemonCore::HandleReq(Stream*, Stream*) ()
#5  0x0000000000590740 in DaemonCore::HandleReqSocketHandler(Stream*) ()
#6  0x0000000000590235 in DaemonCore::CallSocketHandler_worker(int, bool, Stream*) ()
#7  0x00000000005906da in DaemonCore::CallSocketHandler_worker_demarshall(void*) ()
#8  0x0000000000651458 in CondorThreads::pool_add(void (*)(void*), void*, int*, char const*) ()
#9  0x00000000005897b9 in DaemonCore::CallSocketHandler(int&, bool) ()
#10 0x000000000058b6b5 in DaemonCore::Driver() ()
#11 0x000000000057e860 in main ()

The problem is that InsertTimer() is expensive because it does a linear search through existing timers to find the appropriate place to insert the timer that enforces NOT_RESPONDING_TIMEOUT for the shadow that has just sent a heartbeat.

The workaround is to set SHADOW_NOT_RESPONDING_TIMEOUT higher.

Proposed Solution

The timers could be stored in a std::multimap with the firing time as the key. This would allow efficient insertion. However, removal or resetting of a timer would still be expensive, because it involves a linear search for a timer with the specified id. This could be solved by having a map of id to timer. When there are many timers registered to fire at the same time, removal or resetting of a timer from the multimap would still be expensive. This would need to be studied. If it is a problem, we could use std::map instead and create our own doubly linked list to handle collisions. Removal of timer objects (given a pointer) from the doubly linked list would be fast.

An alternative solution is to not have one timer per child. Instead, periodically do a sweep over all children to see if any have stalled. This would sacrifice accuracy of enforcement of NOT_RESPONDING_TIMEOUT. The parent process could be late by as much as the sweeping interval to notice that a child is not responding. That seems perfectly acceptable.

Making timer management scale has the advantage that it could benefit other situations in condor where there are large numbers of timers. However, it is a more complicated change than simply having a single timer to check for hung children.
